title-group.article-title: An enhanced obstacle avoidance and path correction mechanism for an autonomous intelligent robot with multiple sensors

article-meta.aff: 1Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, Taiwan
2Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center (GEODAC), National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
3Department of Information Management, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Yuan Chen, Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, No. 4–18, Ming Shen Rd, Pingtung 90003, Taiwan Email: cyc@mail.npue.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An enhanced obstacle avoidance and path correction mechanism with behavioral strategy is developed by using three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor for a small-size humanoid autonomous intelligent robot which can detect environmental information and correct the path automatically with 4 degrees-of-freedom to perform three types of walking motions, walking forward, turning left and turning right. A field test is conducted to verify the proposed mechanism with three experiments. The results show that the proposed mechanism outperforms previous research of robot obstacle avoidance in moving time, turning times and moving steps.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Autonomous intelligent robot navigation has been a challenging problem over the past couple of decades. Despite the significant advances in this field (Chen and Huang, 2011; Shih et al., 2011b, 2011c; Chevallereau et al., 2008; Joh et al., 1991; Kim et al., 2010; Plestan et al., 2003; Sugiura et al., 2010), comfortable solutions have not yet been developed. Nowadays, most prior robot navigation algorithms are either tailored toward particular structured environments or are driven by an overwhelming degree of computational complexity (Burgard et al., 2005). Potential missions of autonomous robots including mining, forestry, military applications, surveillance and fire rescue missions where a type of biped robot is required to avoid obstacles and correct the path for these tasks. Biped robots, rather than other kinds of robots, are usually ideal for moving about in spatially confined areas and evading obstacles (Bloss, 2007; Braun and Goldfarb, 2009).

A mobile biped robot can provide short-range remote eyes and ears for a variety of potential missions where their mobility allows them to be transported easily and deployed extensively (Casper and Murphy, 2003). Meanwhile, mobile robots have flexible deployment and low cost for providing one mission. Although the mobility of the biped robot makes them adaptable to dynamic environments, how to minimize their size creates great challenges. The difficulties of locomotion (Asano and Luo, 2008) and how to package sensing (Ippoliti et al., 2009), computing and power subsystems into a limited space are the crucial problems. Therefore, how to utilize the tightly constrained space, make efficient use of batteries and choose components carefully, as well as ensuring each individual part is small enough for on-board computation (Braunl and Graf, 2000), communication (Ozturk and Nagarnaik, 2010) and sensing (Lin and King, 2010) resources with limited power consumption are compelling problems (Joh et al., 2010). Several design requirements (Udengaard and Iagnemma, 2009) are needed to make sure the obstacle avoidance can work effectively. The robot must be as mobile as possible to avoid obstacles easily.

In the current research, a mechanical structure with 4 degrees-of-freedom is designed and implemented in a small-size humanoid robot with three types of walking motion: walk forward, turn left and turn right. Meanwhile, three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor are installed. A decision tree method is used to decide behavior from these three types of movements to avoid obstacles, correct the path and effectively proceed to the destination based on information from sensors.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: The decision tree is a well-known decision structure which is a powerful and popular decision support tool that uses a tree-like graph or model of decisions and their possible consequences, including chance event outcomes, resource costs, and utility.

As decision support tools, decision trees have several advantages. First of all, it is simple to understand and interpret. People are able to understand decision tree models after a brief explanation (Lee, 2010; Lee et al., 2010; Lee and Lin, 2011). Secondly, it has value even with little hard data. Important insights can be generated based on experts describing a situation (its alternatives, probabilities, and costs) and their preferences for outcomes. Then, it uses a white box model. If a given result is provided by a model, the explanation for the result is easily replicated by simple mathematics. In addition, it can be combined with other decision techniques. Decision trees can be applied to many fields, such as pattern recognition (Bajla et al., 2009), classification (Yasami and Mozaffari, 2010), decision support systems, expert systems (Exarchos et al., 2007), robot control (Chen and Huang, 2011), and dynamic identification (Chen et al., 2010a, 2010b, 2010c; Chen, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c; Chen, 2011a, 2011b, 2011c), to help identify a strategy most likely to reach a goal. Another use of decision trees is as a descriptive means for calculating conditional probabilities. When the decisions or consequences are modeled by computational verb, then we call the decision tree a computational verb decision tree.

How to make a robot move to the target location and avoid obstacles in real time has been an important studied subject. The Bug algorithm (Lumelsky and Stepanov, 1990) proposed to follow the contour of each obstacle in the robot’s way and made the robot circumnavigate it. Koren and Borenstein (1991a, 1991b) introduced the potential field methods (PFM) and their inherent limitation where its known problem is that the robot gets easily trapped in a U-shape structure. The vector field histogram (VFH) is an obstacle avoidance method that selects a motion direction from a pre-calculated set of solutions (valleys), switching among three different situations: wide-valley situation, narrow-valley situation, and the situation that the robot faces into the target direction (Borenstein and Koren, 1991). When the robot navigates from very dense environments to less dense ones, the turning of the robot should be different. An improved VFH (VFH+) with additional considerations of threshold hysteresis, the robot’s size, and masking blocked sectors is proposed by Ulrich and Borenstein (Ulrich and Borenstein, 1998). Another obstacle avoidance technique is the dynamic window approach (Fox et al., 1997).

The motion commands (translational and rotational velocities of the robot) are carried out directly in the velocity space with an objective function including the heading to the target, the robot’s forward velocities and obstacle clearance is considered. The motion commands are computed by optimizing the objective function.

Other notable results include an interactive multiple model algorithm (Kim and Hong, 2005), a three-layer control architecture (deliberative, sequencing, reflexive) (Hong et al., 2008), a collision-free motion coordination for multiple heterogeneous robots (Ko et al., 2008), a predictive navigation approach with non-holonomic and minimum turning radius constraints (Widyotriatmo et al., 2009), a time-varying feedback control via the chained form (Tamba et al., 2009), and others (Borenstein and Koren, 1998; Castillo et al., 2006; Chen et al., 2011a, 2011b, 2011c; Ngo and Hong, 2009; Ngo et al., 2009).

sec.title: 3.1. Mechanical design
sec.p: An autonomous humanoid robot is implemented in this research to verify the proposed method. Every standard locomotion choice has its pros and cons (Zhao et al., 2009) and three ultrasonic sensors, as well as one compass sensor, are used as its eyes. One compass sensor is used to acquire the environmental information like distance and azimuth angle. Meanwhile, two servo motors are used for locomotion. Furthermore, an intelligent brick (NXT) is utilized to control perceive, computation and action. It also receives information from the three ultrasonic sensors to make decisions (Jolly et al., 2007) for the next movement: forward, left or right. The intelligent brick also receives information from the compass sensor, such as the current azimuth angle. Three ultrasonic sensors are used to provide distance information in a control program with branch-like decision making ability; the azimuth angle information from the compass sensor is used to provide path correction function (Haverinen and Kemppainen, 2009).

sec.title: 3.2. Control program design
sec.p: The branch-like decision making and action control ability for obstacle avoidance and path correction is implemented in Lego Mindstorms NXT with NXT-G to develop the robot’s decision making (Maeda et al., 1993). The obstacle avoidance and path correction program serves as a central control unit commanding the two servo motors through the intelligent brick. The program instructs the robot to move, turn or stop where the decision is based on input from the three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor.

sec.title: 3.3. Obstacle avoidance and path correct by using the decision tree method
sec.p:
The robot continues to move forward until it comes close to an obstacle and then goes into decision-making mode. A decision tree method based on three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor is proposed as shown in Figure 1 (Seraji and Howard, 2002). Meanwhile, the pseudo code is show in Figure 2. The behavioral output of the decision tree is the robot’s three basic motions including go forward, turn left and turn right. Eight behavioral situations (Atyabi et al., 2010) and their corresponding movements (Cheein et al., 2010) are described in Table 1. The obstacle avoidance and path correcting strategy will check the relative behavior (McDowell et al., 2007) from the decision tree (Wang et al., 2008) before the robot moves. After the robot navigates around an obstacle, and in a safe situation, it will continue moving forward and correcting its path until it reaches a safe situation (situation B8). The program will continue performing these decision processes until there are no more obstacles. Figure 1.
Decision tree for the humanoid obstacle avoidance and path correct strategy. Figure 2.
Pseudo code of the proposed method. Table 1.
Behavior table for the decision tree

sec.title: 4.1. Experimental results
sec.p:
An experiment was conducted to verify the feasibility of the obstacle avoidance and path correction decision tree. The experimental environment was an enclosed area within a laboratory. The experimental environment arrangement is shown in Figure 3. Three trajectories of the robot’s movement are shown in Figure 4. Meanwhile, three experiments’ data of forward steps, turning times, correcting times of paths and the time of the whole process are shown in Figures 5, 6 and 7. Figure 3.
Environment arrangement for experiment. Figure 4.
Trajectory of robot’s movement. Figure 5.
Experimental data (forward steps). Figure 6.
Experimental data (turning times). Figure 7.
Experimental data (duration).

When the first experiment begins, the robot moves forward until it meets an obstacle at its right side. Then, the decision process is processed to decide which behavior should be chosen for carrying out the next step. Since the left side distance is longer than the right side distance, the robot makes a left turn to avoid the obstacle and it continues moving forward to walk around the obstacle. After walking around the obstacle, the robot encounters another obstacle and it will acquire the environment information from the three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor. At this moment, the right side distance is longer than the left side distance, and the robot makes a right turn to avoid the obstacle. After passing the obstacle, the robot continues forward again. When the robot reaches its destination it stops. The detailed processes of the second and third experiments are also shown in Figures 5, 6 and Figure 7.

sec.title: 4.2. Experiment result discussion
sec.p: Through three experiments, the obstacle avoidance decision tree with path correction method is validated with reliability. In addition, the efficiency of the control program and the biped walking structure are evaluated. Three indoor experiments demonstrate that the proposed method performs a robust and fast obstacle avoidance and path correction function. Comparing with the method proposed by Shih et al. (2011a), the proposed decision tree method only needs about 1 minute and 3 seconds to cross over three obstacles. If using the other obstacle avoidance method (Shih et al., 2011a), it needs more than 1 minute and 31 seconds to cross over three obstacles. Three experiments show the good performance of the obstacle avoidance and path correction ability. The experiment results also indicate this obstacle avoidance decision tree with path correction method is very effective.

sec.title: 5. Discussions
sec.p: An enhanced obstacle avoidance and path correction mechanism with behavioral strategy is developed by using three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor for a small-size humanoid autonomous intelligent robot which can detect environmental information and correct the path automatically with 4 degrees-of-freedom to perform three types of walking motions, walking forward, turning left and turning right. A field test is conducted to verify the proposed mechanism with three experiments. The results show that the proposed mechanism outperforms the previous research of robot obstacle avoidance in moving time, turning times and moving steps. To achieve the goal of a robust bipedal robot, the NXT-G program is used to design the control program of the robot. The experimental results show the good performance of the obstacle avoidance and path correction functions.

The experiment results indicate that this kind of hardware and software structure is very effective. In other words, to implement a biped robot with obstacle avoidance and path correction function; using Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model and NXT-G is the lowest cost to make it. By using Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model will save much money (Xie et al., 2009) and also meet the goal of building a robust bipedal robot with three ultrasonic sensors and one compass sensor. The Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model structure also allows users to add more sensors when additional functions are required.

Although the results appear promising, the developed robot has some limits. In particular, the environment does not guarantee optimal performance every time, especially when an obstacle may interfere with the ultrasonic sensor’s detection ability. The slipperiness of the floor could also hamper the robot’s walking ability. In other words, when the floor is slippery (Tada and Hosoda, 2007), the robot may not walk in a straight line. To have the best working results, the robot must walk in rough and dry circumstances. There remains a lot of research work to be completed; the detail will be mention in next paragraph.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions and implications for biped robot … researcher and future research
sec.p: In conclusion, the enhanced obstacle avoidance and path correction method proposed in this research was validated through a field test conducted at a closed area in the authors’ laboratory building. The Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model and decision tree structure control program has been totally validated via simple experiment, and the experiment result shows that this improved method could make robot walk through three obstacles smoothly and also correct the walking path in the same time. The key point is using a low cost device that can have the same performance as an expensive device.

The implications of these preliminary results are twofold. At first, although the Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model is a low cost device and only has 4 degrees-of-freedom it still does the work as well as other more expensive devices. It says that a biped robot researcher can save much money when they need to do some research because Lego Mindstorms NXT Alpha Rex Model can provide them with a low cost way of doing biped robot researches.

The second implication of the results is that the decision tree structural program can be used in many situations. Such as high-risk, rough terrain scenarios, planetary exploration, mining, forestry, hazardous site clean-up, and military applications. When in these situations robots need more precise movement. A decision tree structural program can provide precise behavior control.

There still remains some future work to be done. To have real time obstacle avoidance and path correction ability, the robot needs an on-line communication function. Hence, future work could be done by using wireless data transmission devices to give the robot the ability to have real time obstacle avoidance and path correction functions.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors are appreciative of the financial support of their funding body. The authors are also most grateful for the kind assistance of the Editor of Journal of Vibration and Control, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which have led to the making of several corrections that have greatly aided us to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.p: This work was supported by the National Science Council, Republic of China (grant numbers NSC 99-2628-E-153-001 and NSC 100-2628-E-153-001).
